root.pub-comments: Due to lack of examination, the author feels that the relationships can sometimes be tenuous at best; however, certain families, including the Middle Sepik and Sepik Hill stocks, have relationships that can be seen easily from looking at the compiled data.
root.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: The languages of the Ramu phylum show clear relationships on all levels with each other, but contrast against the Sepik phylum with less complex morphologies. Structural relationship is higher than lexical. Speakers: 47483
child.geography: Spoken in the Middle and Upper Keram River area in the extreme eastern part of the East Sepik Province and the Ramu River area in the extreme western part of the Madang Province
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: The Grass stock, Yuat stock and Nor-Pondo languages share many structural and lexical features, and some are also chared by the Mongol-Langam family. Speakers: 11878

child.pub-comments: Due to its higher relationship with the Ramu stock, the Yuat stock was combined with the Ramu stock to give the Ramu super stock, because the Yuat stock clearly did not show much relatinship with the Sepik phylum. Speakers: 8924
child.geography: Spoken in the area of the Middle Yuat River, in the east of the East Sepik Province
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: The Grass stock, Yuat stock and Nor-Pondo languages share many structural and lexical features, and some are also chared by the Mongol-Langam family. Speakers: 1406
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: The Waibuk family is possibly a member of the Trans-New Guinea phylum. If so, the number of Yuat-family speakers would be 5624 and the Ramu subphylum 44183Speakers: 3300
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Not to be confused with Wapi, a dialect of the Olo language of the Torricelli phylum. Laycock (1973a, 1975c) mentions the uncensused village of Erem in the Upper Yuat area as possibly Pinai speaking. It may, however, speak Wapi, or perhaps an unknown fifth language of the Waibuk family. Speakers: 1000
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: W. Foley found that the language spoken at Maramba village which Laycock (1973a) shows as Angoram-speaking, was a different language not belonging to the Nor-Pondo stock. It is probably a language linking with those of the Yuat stock-level family and has been tentatively included, as a family-level isolate, into a newly established Yuat stock comprising also the former Yuat stock-level family. Speakers: 300
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Bun is so closely related to Biwat that it may be a dialect of it. Speakers: 194
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Gapun used to be included in the Torricelli phylum, but has recently been reclassified. Speakers: 74
child.geography: Spoken south of the northeastern extremity of the Nor-Pondo stock
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Both lexical and structural relationships are very close within this stock. Speakers: 134334
child.geography: Spoken in an area extending from the Irian Jaya border eastwards through the Upper Sepik, Yellow River and Lower May River areas to Middle Sepik and much of the country between the Middle Sepik and the coast in the Wewak area
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Yau is not to be confused with the Yau language of the Wapei family of the Torricelli phylum. Speakers: 300
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Pasi is very closely related to Mayo and may be part of the Yau dialect of the latter. Speakers: 161

child.pub-comments: Freudenburg (1976) refers to subdialects by A, B, C, D, etc. However, the present writer has chosen the names of the most populous villages of given subdialect areas to name the respective subdialects. Speakers: 2696

child.pub-comments: Laycock (1973a) mentions the possibility that at least two separate languages may be subsumed under Sawos. Speakers: 8200

child.pub-comments: What is referred to as the Kwasengen language was formerly regarded as the West Wosera dialect of Abelam (Laycock 1973a). However, Wilsom (1976) established that it is a separate language closely related to Abelam. Speakers: 3140

child.pub-comments: Members of the SIL regard Iwam as constituting two distinct languages referred to by them as "May River Iwam" and "Sepik Iwam". Laycock (1973a and in Laycock-Z'graggen 1975) prefers to regard these two communlaects as dialects of a single language which he called "Upriver dialect" and "Downriver dialect". Speakers: 1368
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Members of the SIL regard Iwam as constituting two distinct languages referred to by them as "May River Iwam" and "Sepik Iwam". Laycock (1973a and in Laycock-Z'graggen 1975) prefers to regard these two communlaects as dialects of a single language which he called "Upriver dialect" and "Downriver dialect". Speakers: 1829

child.pub-comments: This stock has unusual multiple noun-classification, but otherwise this stock is very closely related to the other stocks. Speakers: 747
child.geography: Spoken on the Leonard-Shcultze River, a southern tributary of Lower Sepik

child.pub-comments: This classification, both within and with the Sepik-Ramu phylum, is not completely certain. The stock exhibits large amounts of morphological decay, and its closest relatives are within the Ramu subphylum, though lexically is still quite distant. However,its phonological features place it closest to the Ramu subphylum. Within the families, there is high levels fo structural relationship, but between the families it is low. Speakers: 11344
child.geography: Spoken near the mouth of the Sepik and further west in the Murik Lakes area
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.geography: Spoken on the Lower Sepik and Middle Karawari River
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: W. Foley found that the language spoken at Maramba village which Laycock (1973a) shows as Angoram-speaking, was a different language not belonging to the Nor-Pondo stock. It is probably a language linking with those of the Yuat stock-level family and has been tentatively included, as a family-level isolate, into a newly established Yuat stock comprising also the former Yuat stock-level family. Speakers: 6200
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: The Karawari dialect of Alamblak is not to be confused with the Karawarilanguage of the Pondo family of the Nor-Pondo stock. Speakers: 1300
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572

child.pub-comments: Biksi is not very close to much of the Sepik stock, but is closest to the Middle Sepik stock. Speakers: 200
child.publications: Wurm, Stephen A. 1982. Papuan languages of Oceania. Tübingen: Gunter Narr Verlag. ISBN 3878083572
